Software architecture,

profile_positions.description:
At Aerovinci, our mission is to make drone operations for data collection "100% autonomous" without any human control. We have developed the world's first fully functional Basestation. Basestation is the central brain of network infrastructure that houses physical elements such as drone, electronics (actuators, contact charging), weather station, data storage, and the internet gateway.

I work as a software developer and architect for Basestation, with the responsibility to develop and maintain an efficient codebase for a fully functional autonomous drone system. This includes design and development of software modules, firmware, interaction with ground sensor nodes and drone communication with ability to remotely command and control (C&C). The product has been created from scratch.

Expertise in:
Software architecture, Design patterns
Advanced C/C++ development (Embedded Linux)
HW/SW Interfacing
Wireless-network infrastructure
Open source development contributor (QGroundControl, MAVLink, Pixhawk/PX4, Ardupilot)
Contributor github (https://github.com/samacumen)

profile_positions.description:
SecureInAir is a young startup company situated at Helmond, Netherlands. 

Designed the complete embedded software for automatic stabilization of 2-axis camera mount system attached to a helicopter. The self-stabilized mount intelligently rotates on these two axes to capture panoramic photographs in minimal time. A software was developed to visualize the predictive behavior of the mount and ascertain its successful panorama even under adverse weather conditions. The various pictures were stitched using augmented reality software offline.

Featured in news item on SecureInAir's website.

Tools/Skillset: Visual Studio .NET (C#), Microcontroller C++, Data analysis, Predictive algorithms

profile_positions.description:
I worked for a dynamic core software development team of MRI healthcare systems in an agile scrum environment.

My role was to develop an interactive Desktop GUI for MRI systems, in use by radiologists for planning 3D patient scans. The raw scans were extracted from hardware in real-time and sent to the network interface. The rendering of 3D images were done using GDI+ (Windows) in high level programming.

Tools: Embedded C, Visual Studio .NET (C#), SQL, GDI+ graphics.
